Guitar Player Question: What are some of the most difficult chords to play on the guitar?
It seems, initially, that chord changes can be some of the most challenging techniques for guitar beginners. Though the look of some guitar chords may seem daunting, it is essential for guitar players to recognize that chord voicings are varied and players have flexibility when it comes to altering shapes. There are many factors to consider when it comes to assessing the complexity of guitar chords. Chords may incorporate extensive finger stretches, awkward finger placement, multiple fretting fingers, or different barre chord voicings on the neck.
Here are some guitar chords that are commonly regarded as particularly challenging to execute:
Cmaj9 (C major 9th) – requires a stretch between the second and fourth frets with the first and third fingers together in the third fret.
B7 (B dominant 7th) – primarily for its large distance for the hand stretching on the bottom three frets as well as the altered positioning required on the second and third strings.
Gbmaj7 (G flat major 7th) -Barre chord placing fingers across all six strings with the need for precise pressure and finger placement on specific frets. As guitarists recognize and build hand-strength over time, their ability to execute these chords improves. With patience and practice through consistent playing regimens, you should be fine! Keep making music, and never stop learning!
